hypotheses: Older people estimate the risk of COVID-19 as being less than younger people.
Women are more concerned about COVID-19 than men.
People especially worry about being infected in places with high public traffic such as public transport and shops or restaurants.
claim.statement: Older people estimate the risk of COVID-19 as being less than younger people.

data.source: Quantitative online survey via an ISO-certified online access panel provider
data.wave_or_subset: Data collected 19–23 March 2020; initial n=1300 completed, after data cleansing n=1242 retained
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual adults (respondents aged 18–74 who indicated they were not infected with COVID-19)
data.access_details: Data collected by an ISO-certified panel provider; no public dataset link or data access procedure provided in the paper
data.notes: All questionnaire items were mandatory. Respondents who completed the survey in under seven minutes were deleted. Age range limited to 18–74 due to panel provider. Sample is reported as online-representative for gender, age and federal-state distribution. Many measures are 5-point Likert items; scales constructed with reported Cronbach's α values.

method.description: A cross-sectional quantitative online survey administered through an ISO-certified panel provider. The questionnaire included measures of cognitive and affective risk perception (three likelihood items; seven fear/insecurity items), 30 psychometric items based on the psychometric paradigm (dread and unknown risk dimensions), 28 coping items (problem-focused and emotion-focused, based on a German adaptation of the Ways of Coping Scale) plus seven concrete behavior items, four trust items, and ten questions on emergency food preparedness. All questions were mandatory. After data collection, respondents who completed the survey too quickly (<7 minutes) were removed and scales were computed (including checks of internal consistency with Cronbach's α). Analyses reported are descriptive statistics (means, SDs, percentages), reliability (Cronbach's α), group comparisons (gender differences, t-tests or equivalent reported with p-values), and correlations (Pearson r where reported).
steps: Design questionnaire including risk perception (cognitive/affective), psychometric items (dread/unknown risk), coping items (problem- and emotion-focused), behavior items, trust items, and emergency food preparedness items.
Program survey and recruit respondents via an ISO-certified online access panel provider.
Collect responses from 19 March to 23 March 2020; ensure all items mandatory.
Remove respondents with completion times under seven minutes (data cleansing).
Compute descriptive statistics (means, SDs, percentages) for individual items and aggregated scales.
Compute scale reliabilities (Cronbach's α) and construct problem-focused and emotion-focused coping scales.
Conduct group comparisons (gender, age groups, federal states) and correlations (e.g., age with coping), report p-values and correlation coefficients where applicable.
Produce tables and figures summarizing risk perception, fear, coping, behaviors, trust, and food preparedness.
method.models: Descriptive statistics (means, SDs, percentages), scale reliability (Cronbach's α), group comparisons (t-tests or equivalent with reported p-values), Pearson correlations (r). No multivariable regression models reported.
method.outcome_variable: Primary outcomes include perceived likelihood of infection (self, family/friends, general), fear/worry measures, psychometric ratings of COVID-19 (dread/unknown risk items), problem-focused and emotion-focused coping scale scores, concrete behavior measures (e.g., increased hand washing, avoiding public places, buying more supplies), trust in institutions, and emergency food preparedness (days of stored food; whether buying more than usual).
method.independent_variables: Sociodemographic variables used in subgroup analyses: age (grouped: 18–29, 30–39, 40–49, 50–59, 60–74), gender (female, male), federal state, urbanicity (household location categories).

results.summary: Key findings: Older respondents estimate their personal risk of COVID-19 infection as lower than younger respondents. Women report more worry and greater endorsement of coping strategies than men. The German population perceives COVID-19 as a serious, novel, globally consequential threat but also believes it is to some extent controllable. Coping strategies are predominantly problem-focused (listening to experts, thinking carefully, avoiding rash actions). High proportions reported behavior changes: ~87% wash/disinfect hands more, ~87% avoid public places, ~85% avoid public transport. About 41.9% reported buying more food supplies than usual; approximately 50% store food for 10–11 days. Trust is highest in hospitals/emergency services and authorities/medical experts; lower trust in politics.
